div.p:
On 28 March 1878, Leo Caubet, Consul for France in Melbourne, wrote to F. Longmore, Commissioner for Crown Lands: 'According to instructions which I have just received from His Excellency Mr Waddington, Minister for Foreign Affairs, I have the honor to beg you to be so kind as to let me have some informations concerning the "timbers" of Australian production. You will find herewith a memorandum containing a [series] of questions on that matter which is of great importance for our Colony [of] Algeria. I would feel much obliged to you Sir, for enabling me to receive the notes [of] your Department on the subject in [order] that I may transmit it to my Government by the next homeward Mail.' On 30 March Longmore forwarded the letter to the Chief Secretary with the minute: 'Would the Hon. The Chief Secretary have the goodness to order a report on these queries to be prepared by the Government Botanist'. The Under Secretary, W. Odgers, referred the letter and the minute to M on 2 April (O78/3206, unit 1082, VPRS 3991/P, Public Record Office, Victoria). Bairnsdale
Vic. M was visiting various parts of Gippsland as a member of the Wattle Bark Commission. 7/4/78.

div.p: To the honorable Graham Berry, M.L.A.,

div.p:
In compliance with the request of the honorable F. Longmore I have the honor to transmit herewith answers to the questions, asked by the Chevalier Caubet, the Consul for France in Melbourne, regarding the timber-trees of Australia. As these questions are identical with those, submitted by the Right honorable the Earl Carnarvon on behalf of the Société d'agriculture of Algeria, and replied to by myself in a recent communication to your office for his Excellency the Governor,
M to G. Berry, 15 March 1878. I have deemed it best to cause a copy of my former answers now to be prepared for transmission also to the French Consulate of Victoria.

p.style: margin-top: 0in; margin-bottom: 0in; text-align: start; hyphenation-ladder-count: no-limit; font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; hyphenate: false; hyphenation-remain-char-count: 2; hyphenation-push-char-count: 2;

div.p: I beg to add, that in the event of any additional information being required by the Chevalier Caubet, I shall make every effort to impart further knowledge from my long experiences of the uses and value of Australian timber, and the means of raising such abroad; and I may be allowed to state, that for 20 years I have aided by my advise in the creation of Australian forests in Algeria.
